title: How to Connect PC to TV

steps.title: Connect your PC to your TV with a male-to-male HDMI cable.
steps.content: Connect your PC to your TV with a male-to-male HDMI cable . The HDMI port on the computer and the HDMI port on the TV will be exactly the same and the HDMI cable should have the same connector on both ends. [1] X Expert Source Luigi Oppido Computer & Tech Specialist Expert Interview. 10 June 2020. If the TV has more than one HDMI port, make note of the port number you plug it into.

steps.title: Change the input
steps.content: Change the input of the TV. Using the buttons on the TV or using the TV remote, press the Input button to change the input of the TV to HDMI. [2] X Research source If your TV has multiple HDMI ports, choose the port that is connected to the computer. Some TVs may do this automatically when they detect a signal.

steps.title: Right-click on the desktop and select Display Settings.
steps.content: Right-click on the desktop and select Display Settings . This will open the display settings menu.

steps.title: Click Detect.
steps.content: Click Detect . This tells the computer to look for the TV you connected. Look to see if there are two squares, labeled 1 and 2, in the display settings window. Your computer may have already detected your TV.

steps.title: Click Identify.
steps.content: Click Identify . This will show a label on each screen so you will know which number has been assigned to your computer monitor, and what number has been assigned to your TV ("1" being the main display and "2" being the secondary display). [3] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click the "Multiple displays" drop-down box and select an option.
steps.content: Click the "Multiple displays" drop-down box and select an option. This will give you a few options for how you want to show your computer on your TV. The options are: [4] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source Duplicate these displays . This will mirror exactly what is on your computer screen on the TV. Extend these displays . This will make your TV an extended part of your desktop. Show only on 1 . This will turn off display number 2. Show only on 2 . This will turn off display number 1.

steps.title: Click Apply.
steps.content: Click Apply . This will change the display settings and apply them to your computer monitor and TV. Your TV should now be connected to your computer. You can further customize each display by clicking on its numbered square and then selecting Advanced display settings . You can also drag and rearrange the squares to change the orientation of the two displays.

steps.title: Connect your computer to the TV with a male-to-male DVI or VGA or cable.
steps.content: Connect your computer to the TV with a male-to-male DVI or VGA or cable. Both the DVI and VGA port on the computer and the TV should be exactly the same and the cable should have the same connector on both ends. On some TV's the VGA input is labeled "PC IN" or "Computer IN".

steps.title: Connect your computer to the TV with a male-to-male audio cable.
steps.content: Connect your computer to the TV with a male-to-male audio cable. This is a 3.5mm stereo audio cable, similar to the end of a headphone plug. Plug one end of the cable into the headphone jack on your computer, which is typically a green port. Then plug the other end into the audio-in port on the TV. The audio-in port on the TV should be located near the DVI or VGA port you connected earlier.

steps.title: Change the input of the TV.
steps.content: Change the input of the TV. Using the buttons on the TV or using the TV remote, press the Input button to change the input of the TV to DVI or VGA. [5] X Research source On some TVs this input is labeled "PC" or "Computer". Some TVs may do this automatically when they detect a signal.

steps.title: Enable Wi-Fi mode on the TV.
steps.content: Enable Wi-Fi mode on the TV. Follow the manufacturer's instructions to do so, access the Miracast protocol settings to configure your TV's Wi-Fi connection. [8] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source [9] X Expert Source Luigi Oppido Computer & Tech Specialist Expert Interview. 10 June 2020. Not all TVs with Wi-Fi support this feature. Check the owner's manual of your TV before continuing.

steps.title: Connect the TV to your Wi-Fi network.
steps.content: Connect the TV to your Wi-Fi network. This must be the same Wi-Fi network that your computer is connected to. [10] X Expert Source Luigi Oppido Computer & Tech Specialist Expert Interview. 10 June 2020.

steps.title: Right-click on the desktop and click Display settings.
steps.content: Right-click on the desktop and click Display settings .

steps.title: Click the "Multiple displays" drop-down box and select Duplicate this display.
steps.content: Click the "Multiple displays" drop-down box and select Duplicate this display . [11] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Apply.
steps.content: Click Apply .

steps.title: Open Start then click .
steps.content: Open Start then click . This will open the main Windows settings.

steps.title: Click Devices then click Connected Devices.
steps.content: Click Devices then click Connected Devices .

steps.title: Click Add a device.
steps.content: Click Add a device . Windows will begin searching for connected devices on the network. [12] X Expert Source Luigi Oppido Computer & Tech Specialist Expert Interview. 10 June 2020.

steps.title: Select your TV when it appears.
steps.content: Select your TV when it appears. Windows will automatically connect to your TV. [13] X Expert Source Luigi Oppido Computer & Tech Specialist Expert Interview. 10 June 2020.

steps.title: Make sure you have the right cables or adapters.
steps.content: Make sure you have the right cables or adapters. Sometimes cables can have the right connections but aren't made for the purpose of carrying audio or video signals. Make sure the cable is rated for audio/visual use. [14] X Research source Most computers don't send audio output through the DVI port, so a DVI to HDMI adapter won't carry any audio in most cases. If so, you'll need to hook up a separate audio cable.

steps.title: Make sure all the cables are connected properly.
steps.content: Make sure all the cables are connected properly. Check that all the cables are plugged in properly to the ports and not loose. If the cable has thumb screws, like most DVI and VGA cables, make sure the screws are screwed in and snug. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Check the volume.
steps.content: Check the volume. Check that the volume is up on both the computer and TV and make sure neither is on mute.

steps.title: Change the audio output.
steps.content: Change the audio output. If you're not getting sound, make sure you have the right audio output selected. [16] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source Right-click on . Click Playback devices . Select the correct audio output (HDMI output for HDMI, or Headphones if you're using an audio cable) If you don't see the right output, right-click on any of the listed devices and make sure Show Disabled Devices and Show Disconnected Devices are both selected. This will tell you if the audio is disconnected or disabled.

steps.title: Restart the computer and the TV.
steps.content: Restart the computer and the TV. When all else fails, restarting the computer and the TV can help the computer to detect that a new display is connected.

steps.title: Check your computer's display calibration.
steps.content: Check your computer's display calibration. Sometimes, an error message will pop up saying "HDMI not supported", which usually pops up when your TV and PC have different display settings for resolution.
